(3) Ozone data set. Environment Executive Agency. https://data.egov.bg/organisation/dataset/fc014514-eafd-401b-a9fb-2a8b90265d9d
(4) Sulfur dioxide data set. Environment Executive Agency. https://data.egov.bg/organisation/dataset/0cc27f05-2663-410a-a3d6-e12434f3dfb7
(5) Carbon monoxide data set. Environment Executive Agency. https://data.egov.bg/organisation/dataset/9e322dc1-6925-4c48-9d8d-aac9b5ed716a
(6)Daily bulletin on the quality of the atmospheric air in the country. Environment Executive Agency. http://eea.government.bg/airq/bulletin.jsp
(7) European Air Quality Index. European Environment Agency. https://airindex.eea.europa.eu/Map/AQI/Viewer/

indicators.justification:
The Measures against Money Laundering Act ("MAMLA") 2018 in its art. 64 requires that all legal entities file and entrusted individuals declare before the Commercial registry and/or BULSTAT registry information on their beneficial owners.(1) This act does not provide for publicity on the beneficial ownership data and refers to the Law on the Commercial Register and the Register of Non-Profit Legal Entities (LCRRNE).(2) Under the Ordinance № 1 of 14 February 2007 on keeping, storing and accessing the Commercial Register and the Register of Non-Profit Legal Entities, Art. 67, par. 50 (3) the specific section "Beneficial owners" of the Commercial Register and the Register of Non-Profit Legal Entities lists on the publicly accessible entity page the names, nationality and state of residence of the beneficial owners. Access for the individual entities data is available online. However, the entire data base or the data on beneficial owners is not available as an aggregated data set or data sets. In principle, Art. 113, par. 1 of the Ordinance provides that the Registry Agency could provide the entire data base or structured part of it to anyone for a fee. However, the researcher could not find such a copy of the data base concerning beneficial ownership.
A sectoral act - the Law on mandatory deposit of printed and other works and on announcing the distribution and delivery of media services (LMDPPOWADDMS) in its art. 7a and 7b provides that the media service providers and the distributors of periodicals (press) declare their beneficial owners before the Ministry of culture.(4) Art. 7c provides that this information should be published in a public online register. However, no data has been officially published for 2019 or 2020. The data could be accessed offline through an access to public information request.

(1) Закон за мерките срещу изпирането на пари (Measures against Money Laundering Act ("MAMLA")). 2018. Lex.bg. https://www.lex.bg/bg/laws/ldoc/2137182924 
(2) Закон за търговския регистър и регистъра на юридическите лица с нестопанска цел (Law on the Commercial Register and the Register of Non-Profit Legal Entities (LCRRNE)). 2006. Lex.bg. https://www.lex.bg/laws/ldoc/2135522741
(3) Наредба № 1 от 14 февруари 2007 г. за водене, съхраняване и достъп до Търговския регистър и регистъра на юридическите лица с нестопанска цел (Ordinance № 1 of 14 February 2007 on keeping, storing and accessing the Commercial Register and the Register of Non-Profit Legal Entities). 2007. https://portal.registryagency.bg/nested-page-file-download/479-1590824310 
(4) Закон за задължително депозиране на печатни и други произведения и обявяване на разпространителите и доставчиците на медийни услуги (the Law on mandatory deposit of printed and other works and on announcing the distribution and delivery of media services (LMDPPOWADDMS)). 2001. Lex.bg. https://lex.bg/laws/ldoc/2134956545

evidence.title: MAMLA
LCRRNE
Ordinance № 1 of 14 February 2007 on keeping, storing and accessing the Commercial Register and the Register of Non-Profit Legal Entities

indicators.justification:
The Law on the Commercial Register and the Register of Non-Profit Legal Entities (LCRRNE)(1) and the Ordinance № 1 of 14 February 2007 on keeping, storing and accessing the Commercial Register and the Register of Non-Profit Legal Entities(2) provide the structuring and publication of the Commercial Register and the Register of Non-Profit Legal Entities. Access for the individual entities data is available online. However, the entire data base is not available as an aggregated data set or data sets. In principle, Art. 113, par. 1 of the Ordinance provides that the Registry Agency could provide the entire data base or structured part of it to anyone for a fee.(3) Payed private services like Ciela, Apis, Lakorda,(4) and others process and integrate data from the Commercial Register and the Register of Non-Profit Legal Entities into their services.

(3) Предоставяне срещу заплащане на цялата база данни на Търговския регистър. https://www.registryagency.bg/bg/registri/targovski-registar/predostavyane-sreshtu-zaplashtane-na-cyalata-baza-danni/

indicators.justification:
The Cadastre and Property Register Act (CPRA) (2000) (1) provides for the establishment of a Property Register organized by property lots, instead of the previously used system of registration of property organized by owners' lots. The Cadastre is the set of basic data about the location, boundaries and extent of immovable property within the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria it also encompasses data on the right of ownership on immovable properties, data on the other real rights over immovable properties, data on the state borders, boundaries of administrative-territorial units, etc. (art. 2 of the CPRA). The Property Register should encompass the lots of the immovable properties including the acts recognizing or conveying right of ownership or establishing, conveying, modifying and terminating other real right over immovable properties, interdictions and mortgages over the latter, etc. The Cadastre (2) which provides data on land types and lots' boundaries and the Property Register (3) which includes all details on the ownership of land lots should be integrated via a unique identifier for each property lot under the CPRA. However, as a recent Court of Auditors audit report points out,(4) the existing Cadastre and Property Register are, so far, entirely matching data for only five (out of 266) municipalities. Some informal integration between the Cadastre and the Property Register is in place since 2009.(4) By January 2020 more than 16 million property lots have been created in the Property Register, however more than 11 million lots do not have a unique identifier and could not be directly linked to the Cadastre. (4) The report concludes that a Property Register as provided for by the CPRA is not yet established. Based on the data in the information system (of the current Property Register), the Registry Agency provides electronic services (i.e. data and excerpts of data), against payment, without ensuring the completeness, accuracy and reliability of the data. (4) Both data sets are not available as a whole, but excerpts from them - maps and data - are available for a fee.

(1) Закон за кадастъра и имотния регистър (Cadastre and Property Register Act (CPRA)).2000. Lex.bg. https://www.lex.bg/laws/ldoc/2134918656 
(2) Кадастрално-административна информационна система (Cadastre). https://kais.cadastre.bg/bg
(3) Property Register. https://portal.registryagency.bg/property-register
(4) ОДИТЕН ДОКЛАД № 0300101019 за извършен одит на "Ефективност на организацията и контрола на дейностите по водене и съхраняване на поддържаните от Агенцията по вписванията регистри" за периода от 01.01.2017 г. до 31.12.2019 г. (AUDIT REPORT № 0300101019 for performed audit of the "Efficiency of the organization and control of the activities of keeping and storage of the registers maintained by the Registry Agency" for the period from 01.01.2017 to 31.12.2019.). Приет с Решение № 259 от 05.08.2021 г. на Сметната палата (Протокол № 30). https://www.bulnao.government.bg/media/documents/od-avtomagistrali-0621.pdf

evidence.title: (1) Закон за кадастъра и имотния регистър (Cadastre and Property Register Act (CPRA)).2000. Lex.bg.
(2) Кадастрално-административна информационна система (Cadastre).
(3) Property Register.

(4) ОДИТЕН ДОКЛАД № 0300101019 за извършен одит на „Ефективност на организацията и контрола на дейностите по водене и съхраняване на поддържаните от Агенцията по вписванията регистри“ за периода от 01.01.2017 г. до 31.12.2019 г. (AUDIT REPORT № 0300101019 for performed audit of the “Efficiency of the organization and control of the activities of keeping and storage of the registers maintained by the Registry Agency” for the period from 01.01.2017 to 31.12.2019.). Приет с Решение № 259 от 05.08.2021 г. на Сметната палата (Протокол № 30).

indicators.justification:
Under the 2018 Act on Counteracting Corruption and on the Forfeiture of Illegally Acquired Property (1) all persons holding high public positions (art. 6) and all civil servants (§ 2. of the Additional provisions of the Act) have to submit declarations on their interests and assets (art. 35). The declarations of the persons holding high public positions are published by the Commission on Counteracting Corruption and on the Forfeiture of Illegally Acquired Property in the electronic public register (art. 169, par. 1 of the Act).(2) The conflicts on interests parts of the declarations of civil servants are published by their respective public body (§ 2., par. 2 of the Additional provisions of the Act). The data is not open. The data can be reused freely as it is public information under the Access to Public Information Act, however, there is no specific license indicated. The data is in Bulgarian - the official national language.
The data from the electronic public register (2) covers: real estate; vehicles; financial resources, including savings and loans; investments; the previous year's income outside of the occupied position; collaterals, etc.
(1) Закон за противодействие на корупцията и за отнемане на незаконно придобитото имущество (Act on Counteracting Corruption and on the Forfeiture of Illegally Acquired Property). 2018. Lex.bg. https://www.lex.bg/en/laws/ldoc/2137180227 
(2) Регистър на лица, заемащи висши публични длъжности (Register of the persons holding high public positions). Commission on Counteracting Corruption and on the Forfeiture of Illegally Acquired Property. https://register.c  aciaf.bg/2020/index.html

indicators.justification:
Political parties have to draw up a financial statement on the preceding calendar year, including information on the headquarters and the regional chapters, under art. 34 of the Political Parties Act (PPA) (2005) (1). This report is published in a public register by the Bulgarian National Audit Office (art. 34, par. 6 of the PPA).(2) Also, the audit reports of political parties' financial statements are published in the same register (art. 35a, par. 4 of the PPA). The parties, coalitions, and initiative committees participating in election campaigns have to file with the Bulgarian National Audit Office the financial statements of income, expenditures and payment commitments in connection with the election campaign, accompanied by a statement from their bank account, up to 30 days after the election, under art. 172 of the Electoral Code.(3) These financial statements are published by the Audit Office in the unified public register under art. 171 of the Electoral Code.(4) Art. 34, 35, and 35a of the PPA and art. 171, and  172 of the Electoral Code provide for a control of the financial statements by the Audit Office and in some cases by the National Revenue Agency (the tax authority).
Both public registers (2) (3) contain the respective annual, or electoral campaign, financial statements for each party, coalition or initiative committee. The Unified Register under the Electoral Code publishes also the list of donors and their donation along with the declarations for the donations, a list of the advertising and media agencies paid in the name of the respective party, coalition or initiative committee, as well as declarations on the origin of the funds of the candidates and the members of the initiative committees. All these are published as documents (often scanned and not machine readable, and most often in the .pdf, .docx or .jpg formats).

NB. At the time of carrying out this survey it seems that the Unified public register under art. 171 of the Electoral Code is only accessible from Bulgaria.

(1) Закон за политическите партии (Political Parties Act) (PPA).2005. Lex.bg. https://www.lex.bg/en/laws/ldoc/2135501352 
(2) Отчети на партии (Parties reports). Bulgarian National Audit Office. https://www.bulnao.government.bg/bg/kontrol-partii/otcheti-na-partii/ 
(3) Изборен кодекс (Electoral Code). 2014. Lex.bg. https://www.lex.bg/laws/ldoc/2136112596 
(4) Единен Регистър по Изборния Кодекс (Unified Register under the Electoral Code). Bulgarian National Audit Office. https://erik.bulnao.government.bg/RegDonors/Default.aspx

indicators.justification:
The 1973 Law on Normative Acts, (1) art. 26, provides that in the process of drafting a normative act, public consultations are held with citizens and legal entities. Before submitting a draft normative act for issuance or adoption by the competent authority, the drafter of the project should publish it on the website of the respective institution together with the reasons, respectively the report, and, in the cases of laws and codes, the preliminary impact assessment. When the compiler of the project is a body of the executive power, the publication should be done on the Public Consultations Portal,(2) and when it is a body of the local self-government - on the website of the respective municipality and / or municipal council. Citizens and organizations have a 30-day period to submit proposals and statements on the project. After the completion of the public consultation period and before the adoption, respectively the issuance of the normative act, the drafter of the project should publish on the website of the respective institution a summary of the received proposals together with a reasons for the not accepted proposals. When the drafter of the project is a body of the executive power, the publication of the report is done simultaneously on the Public Consultations Portal. Under art. 28, par. 4 of the Law, a draft normative act, to which no reasons and, in some cases preliminary impact assessment, have been attached, should not be discussed by the competent authority.
Hence, the data most oftenly published are: the heading of the proposed document; the proposed legal (or strategic) document; the reasons for its adoption; the partial preliminary impact assessment; a statement by the Council of Ministers' Administration on the impact assessment; in some cases a table of transposition of the relevant EU legislation; in some cases an ex post impact assessment; all comments and statements received during the public consultation period; after the end of the consultation period a summary of the proposals and statements received and whether they were adopted or not in the final version of the consulted document; the start and end dates of the consultation period; the target groups for the consultation; the sphere of governance.
This information is being published as documents often scanned and not machine readable.(2)

(1) Закон за нормативните актове (Law on Normative Acts). 1973. Lex.bg. https://www.lex.bg/en/mobile/ldoc/2127837184

(2) Портал за обществени консултации (Public Consultations Portal). https://strategy.bg/PublicConsultations/List.aspx?lang=bg-BG&sortDirection=Descending&sortExpression=OpenningDate&typeConsultation=1&typeCategory=0&docType=0&obshtiniValue=0

evidence.title: (1) Закон за нормативните актове (Law on Normative Acts). 1973. Lex.bg.
(2) Портал за обществени консултации (Public Consultations Portal).

indicators.justification:
The government's support for data reuse consists of the annual publication of a Decision of the Council of Ministers,(1) drafted by the State E-Government Agency, to publish new open data sets under art. 15b, par. 3 of the Access to public information act (APIA) 2000.(2) These annuals Decisions include a large variety of data sets from different government bodies. In the May 2019 – May 2021 period, the State E-Government Agency organized one promotional event on open data and reuse – an online conference in December 2020 "Open dialogue for open data".(3) The recording of the conference and some of its documents are published on the Open Data Portal, hence aimed to the attention of all citizens and organizations.
The government through the Ministry of Education created in 2020 a specific data portal – the Bulgarian Portal for Open Science, aimed and scholars and academia.(4)

indicators.justification:
Regional government is very limited in its powers and directly subordinated to the central government, hence this answer will only focus on local government. Some regional administrations publish information on the Open Data Portal. 262 out of 266 municipalities in Bulgaria have a profile in the government Open Data Portal and some of them publish data in it.(1) Some municipalities or units from them have their own ad hoc initiatives like the municipal company SofiaPlan of the Sofia (the Capital) Municipality which has published an open data library for its Vision for Sofia project.(2) There are no general open data policies on the regional ot local level.

(1) Open Data Portal. Organizations. Search word: municipalities. https://data.egov.bg/organisation?q=%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%89%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0&type=2

indicators.justification:
The Institute of Public Administration (IPA) is a structure of the Council of Ministers of the Republic of Bulgaria and is the leading institution for training of civil servants in the public administration. In the 2019-2021 period it offered between two and five training courses on open data: 2019 E-5 Data bases analysis and visualizations; 2019 OP1 Innovation lab; 2020 P-10 Open data in government; 2020 DK-5 Data bases analysis and visualizations; 2020 DK-6 Data bases analysis and visualizations (advanced); 2021 P13 High-value data sets; 2021 P10 Open data in government: Quality and impact of open data; 2021 DK 5 Data bases analysis and visualizations (basic); 2021 DK-6 Data bases analysis and visualizations (advanced); 2021 OP1 Practical work with open data – upgrading training. All the trainings are listed in further detail in the Institutes respective catalogues for 2019, (1) 2020, (2), and 2021 (3).
These trainings are available to all central executive bodies, as well as to the local government bodies. In the 2019-2021 period all the trainings gathered 68 groups and a total of 1102 trainees which compared to the 570+ executive (including local government) bodies is not a very high coverage.
(1) 2019 IPA Catalogue https://www.ipa.government.bg/sites/default/files/katalog_obuchenia_ipa_2019_online_0_0.pdf

indicators.justification:
Under the Civil Registration Act (1) all Bulgarian citizens and residents have unique identifiers – a unique civic number (or unique foreigner number). Under the Law on the Commercial Register and the Register of Non-Profit Legal Entities (LCRRNE) (2) and the BULSTAT Register Act (3) all legal entities and single person professionals have also identifiers – the unique identification code and the BULSTAT number. These identifiers along with the names of persons and entities are public and common for all national registers. There is some interoperability between the Commercial Register and the Register of Non-Profit Legal Entities, the Property Register and the Cadastre Register.(4) However, since all those datasets are not published as open data any crossing between them should be done "by hand."

indicators.justification:
The Measures against Money Laundering Act ("MAMLA") 2018 in its art. 64 requires that all legal entities file and entrusted individuals declare before the Commercial registry and/or BULSTAT registry information on their beneficial owners.(1) The data of the beneficial owners are listed in the Commercial Register and the Register of Non-Profit Legal Entities either as executives or members of the boards of the legal entity, or, if they do not occupy such positions, in a specific section of the entity's profile called "Beneficial owners" under the Law on the Commercial Register and the Register of Non-Profit Legal Entities (LCRRNE), art. 19, par. 4 in relation with art. 11.(2) Under Ordinance № 1 of 14 February 2007 on keeping, storing and accessing the Commercial Register and the Register of Non-Profit Legal Entities, Art. 67, par. 50 the specific section "Beneficial owners" of the Commercial Register and the Register of Non-Profit Legal Entities lists on the publicly accessible entity page the names, nationality and state of residence of the beneficial owners.(5)
A sectoral act - the Law on mandatory deposit of printed and other works and on announcing the distribution and delivery of media services (LMDPPOWADDMS) 2001 in its art. 7a and 7b provides that the media service providers and the distributors of periodicals (press) declare their beneficial owners before the Ministry of culture. Art. 7c provides that this information should be published in a public online register.(3)

indicators.justification:
There are no data specific provisions for accessibility, however, some legal requirements could be interpreted as applicable to data or certain types of data collection and publication by public bodies. Directive (EU) 2016/2102 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 26 October 2016 on the accessibility of the websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies(1) provides some general rules which have transposed in art. 58c of the Electronic Government Act(2) and in art. 39 and 39a of the Ordinance of the Council of Ministers on the general requirements for information systems, registers and electronic administrative services (3). Under art. 58c of the Electronic Government Act all public sector bodies ensure the accessibility of the content of their websites and mobile applications in accordance with the applicable harmonized standards, parts thereof or technical specifications.(2) Art. 39 adds that the Chairman of the State E-Gov Agency approves recommendations for user interfaces, and the content of the websites and mobile applications of administrative authorities, public service providers and public officials must comply with the harmonized standard EN 301 549 V2.1.2. These rules also apply to the data published as content of the respective websites and mobile applications. These rules, however, have multiple exceptions for public radio and TV providers, schools, kindergartens or nurseries, for data concerning maps and maps services, third party data, cultural heritage objects, as well as when involving a disproportionate burden. All public bodies must draft and publish accessibility information.

(1) Directive (EU) 2016/2102 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 26 October 2016 on the accessibility of the websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies. 2016. EUR-Lex. https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/ALL/?uri=CELEX%3A32016L2102
(2) Закон за електронното управление (Electronic Government Act). 2007. Lex.bg. https://www.lex.bg/laws/ldoc/2135555445 
(3) Наредба за общите изисквания към информационните системи, регистрите и електронните административни услуги (Ordinance of the Council of Ministers on the general requirements for information systems, registers and electronic administrative services). 2017. Lex.bg. https://www.lex.bg/bg/laws/ldoc/2136995819

indicators.justification:
Data in the Bulgarian administration is gathered, processed and published through registers which could be internal, i.e. only for the administrative body's purposes, or public; and depending on its support – paper-based or electronic. The Electronic Government Act (1) in its article 43, par. 2 sets a rule for the general interoperability of electronic registers and refers to a bylaw – the Ordinance of the Council of Ministers on the general requirements for information systems, registers and electronic administrative services (2). The Ordinance – art. 5 – provides general rules for registers and data bases related to the provision of administrative services, and which are not paper-based or processed through office applications. Hence, the rules are general but provide a large exception for all registers not related to administrative services, or processed on paper or office applications. These rules cover identification of registers and data bases (art. 6), access to registers and data bases (art. 7), conditions on access (art. 8), certification administrative services (art. 9), identification in a register or data base (art. 10), some data requirements (art. 11), logs (art. 12), mergers of registers (art. 13), version and alterations management (art. 14), some open data requirements (art. 15), and interoperability (Section III). The art. 15, par. 6 of the Ordinance (2) provides that administrative bodies should follow the recommendations of the World Wide Web Consortium: Data on the Web Best Practices 2016, and Best Practices for Publishing Linked Data 2014.
The Electronic Government Act - art. 1 - and the Ordinance are general and apply to all administrative bodies, i.e. from the Executive branch of government.

(1) Закон за електронното управление (Electronic Government Act). 2007. Lex.bg. https://www.lex.bg/laws/ldoc/2135555445 
(2) Наредба за общите изисквания към информационните системи, регистрите и електронните административни услуги (Ordinance of the Council of Ministers on the general requirements for information systems, registers and electronic administrative services). 2017. Lex.bg. https://www.lex.bg/bg/laws/ldoc/2136995819

indicators.justification:
Depending on the sector and the particular data, different rules and/or agreements on specific data sharing exist between public bodies and between public and private entities. There is no comprehensive framework. However, the Council of Ministers and the State e-Government Agency have put in place and develop an inter-registry data exchange environment (RegiX) which is a means of sharing data between public bodies from different, but not all, public registers. (1)
The Council of Ministers and the State e-Government Agency have put in place and develop an inter-registry data exchange environment (RegiX). This is a means of sharing data between public bodies from different, but not all, public registers focused on cutting red tape for citizens. (2)
The RegiX framework covers multiple government agencies from the central government. It is mainly focused on allowing public bodies to perform a check or a confirmation of data on a person or a legal entity. Other specific contracts or rules exist where government bodies provide data to certain citizens or legal entities either for free under a specific contract, or for a fee.
(1) Inter-registry data exchange environment (RegiX). http://regixaisweb.egov.bg/regixinfo

indicators.justification:
The Constitution of the Republic of Bulgaria – art. 32 and art. 34 – provide the legal basis for the inviolability of the privacy of citizens and of their freedom and confidentiality of correspondence and all other communications. (1) The Republic of Bulgaria is a member of the European Union (EU). The Regulation (EU) 2016/679 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 27 April 2016 on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data, and repealing Directive 95/46/EC (GDPR) (2) has a direct effect and is directly applicable in Bulgaria's legal order. The Regulation's provisions that need to be specified are implemented and completed on the national level by the Personal data protection act. (3)
The EU personal data protection framework of which the GDPR is a part applies to all sectors. An exception to the GDPR, but as a part of the EU personal data protection framework is the sector of Law enforcement, which is covered by the Directive (EU) 2016/680 on the protection of natural persons regarding processing of personal data connected with criminal offenses or the execution of criminal penalties, and on the free movement of such data which (4) is also implemented on the national level by the Personal data protection act.
(1) Constitution of the Republic of Bulgaria. 1991. National Assembly. https://www.parliament.bg/en/const
(2) Regulation (EU) 2016/679 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 27 April 2016 on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data, and repealing Directive 95/46/EC (GDPR). 2016. EUR-Lex. https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/reg/2016/679/oj
(3) Personal data protection act. 2002. Commission for Personal Data Protection. https://www.cpdp.bg/en/index.php?p=element&aid=1194 
(4) Directive (EU) 2016/680 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 27 April 2016 on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data by competent authorities for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties, and on the free movement of such data, and repealing Council Framework Decision 2008/977/JHA. 2016. EUR-Lex. https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=uriserv%3AOJ.L_.2016.119.01.0089.01.ENG

indicators.justification:
Directive (EU) 2019/1024 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 June 2019 on open data and the re-use of public sector information (1) currently awaits transposition. The no longer in force Directive 2013/37/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 26 June 2013 amending Directive 2003/98/EC on the re-use of public sector information, (2) the Access to public information act (APIA), 2000, (3) and the Ordinance on the licenses for re-use of public sector information and for its publication in open format (Ordinance), 2016, (4) provide a comprehensive framework for generating and publishing open data.
Art. 15b of the APIA provides for an annual planning of publishing open data sets both on the individual body level and at the general executive level under the Council of Ministers. This planning leads to some coordination by the Council of Ministers, as well as sporadic trainings and capacity building.

indicators.justification:
Under the 2018 Act on Counteracting Corruption and on the Forfeiture of Illegally Acquired Property (1) all persons holding high public positions (art. 6) and all civil servants (§ 2. of the Additional provisions of the Act) have to submit declarations on their interests and assets (art. 35). The declarations of the persons holding high public positions are published by the Commission on Counteracting Corruption and on the Forfeiture of Illegally Acquired Property in the electronic public register (art. 169, par. 1 of the Act).(2) The conflicts on interests parts of the declarations of civil servants are published by their respective public body (§ 2., par. 2 of the Additional provisions of the Act). The data is not open.

indicators.justification:
Political parties have to draw up a financial statement on the preceding calendar year, including information on the headquarters and the regional chapters, under art. 34 of the Political Parties Act (PPA) (2005) (1). This report is published in a public register by the Bulgarian National Audit Office (art. 34, par. 6 of the PPA).(2) Also, the audit reports of political parties' financial statements are published in the same register (art. 35a, par. 4 of the PPA). The parties, coalitions, and initiative committees participating in election campaigns have to file with the Bulgarian National Audit Office the financial statements of income, expenditures and payment commitments in connection with the election campaign, accompanied by a statement from their bank account, up to 30 days after the election, under art. 172 of the Electoral Code.(3) These financial statements are published by the Audit Office in the unified public register under art. 171 of the Electoral Code.(4) Art. 34, 35, and 35a of the PPA and art. 171, and  172 of the Electoral Code provide for a control of the financial statements by the Audit Office and in some cases by the National Revenue Agency (the tax authority).

(1) Закон за политическите партии (Political Parties Act) (PPA).2005. Lex.bg. https://www.lex.bg/en/laws/ldoc/2135501352 
(2) Отчети на партии (Parties reports). Bulgarian National Audit Office. https://www.bulnao.government.bg/bg/kontrol-partii/otcheti-na-partii/ 
(3) Изборен кодекс (Electoral Code). 2014. Lex.bg. https://www.lex.bg/laws/ldoc/2136112596 
(4) Единен Регистър по Изборния Кодекс (Unified Register under the Electoral Code). Bulgarian National Audit Office. https://erik.bulnao.government.bg/RegDonors/Default.aspx

indicators.justification:
The 1973 Law on Normative Acts, (1) art. 26, provides that in the process of drafting a normative act, public consultations are held with citizens and legal entities. Before submitting a draft normative act for issuance or adoption by the competent authority, the drafter of the project should publish it on the website of the respective institution together with the reasons, respectively the report, and, in the cases of laws and codes, the preliminary impact assessment. When the compiler of the project is a body of the executive power, the publication should be done on the Public Consultations Portal,(2) and when it is a body of the local self-government - on the website of the respective municipality and / or municipal council. Citizens and organizations have a 30-day period to submit proposals and statements on the project. After the completion of the public consultation period and before the adoption, respectively the issuance of the normative act, the drafter of the project should publish on the website of the respective institution a summary of the received proposals together with a reasons for the not accepted proposals. When the drafter of the project is a body of the executive power, the publication of the report is done simultaneously on the Public Consultations Portal. Under art. 28, par. 4 of the Law, a draft normative act, to which no reasons and, in some cases preliminary impact assessment, have been attached, should not be discussed by the competent authority.
Information on draft normative acts, public consultations and summaries of the consultations are being published as documents (often scanned and not machine readable).(2)
(1) Закон за нормативните актове (Law on Normative Acts). 1973. Lex.bg. https://www.lex.bg/en/mobile/ldoc/2127837184 
(2) Портал за обществени консултации (Public Consultations Portal). https://strategy.bg/PublicConsultations/List.aspx?lang=bg-BG&sortDirection=Descending&sortExpression=OpenningDate&typeConsultation=1&typeCategory=0&docType=0&obshtiniValue=0

evidence.title: (1) Закон за нормативните актове (Law on Normative Acts). 1973. Lex.bg.
(2) Портал за обществени консултации (Public Consultations Portal).

indicators.justification:
Under art. 15, par. 2 of the Access to Public Information Act every head of administrative structure (central and local government included) should prepare an annual report on the applications for access to public information and on the re-use of public sector information, which shall contain among others data on the refusals made and the reasons therefor. This information should published on the Internet sites of the administrative structures (art. 15a). For statistics on the level of implementation see the Access to Information Programme annual Survey.(2)
